content: Singaporean politician **Teo Chee Hean** [PPA(E)](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam_(Tentera)) ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 张志贤; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *Tioⁿ Chì-hiân*; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Zhāng Zhìxián*; born 27 December 1954) is a Singaporean former politician and two-star [rear-admiral](/wiki/Rear-admiral) who served as [Senior Minister of Singapore](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore) and [Coordinating Minister for National Security](/wiki/Coordinating_Minister_for_National_Security_(Singapore)) from 2019 and 2015 respectively until 2025. He served as the [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) (MP) representing the [Pasir Ris West](/wiki/Pasir_Ris) division of [Pasir Ris–Punggol Group Representation Constituency](/wiki/Pasir_Ris%E2%80%93Punggol_Group_Representation_Constituency) from 2001 to 2025. A recipient of the [President's Scholarship](/wiki/President%27s_Scholar) and [Singapore Armed Forces Overseas Scholarship](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces_Overseas_Scholarship), Teo served in the [Republic of Singapore Navy](/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy) (RSN) between 1972 and 1992, and attained the rank of [Rear-Admiral](/wiki/Rear-Admiral) (Two-Star). He served as Chief of Navy in 1991 and 1992 before leaving the Navy and entering politics. He made his political debut in the [1992 by-election](/wiki/1992_Marine_Parade_by-election) in [Marine Parade GRC](/wiki/Marine_Parade_Group_Representation_Constituency) as part of a four-member PAP team. He had served as 6th [Deputy Prime Minister](/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) between 2009 and 2019, [Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment) between 1995 and 1997, [Minister for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) between 1997 and 2003, [Minister for Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)) between 2003 and 2011 and [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) between 2011 and 2015. Teo was part of the ministerial committee of the Smart Nation and Digital Government Group (SNDGG). As Senior Minister, Teo had served as acting prime minister in several occasions, during Prime Minister [Lee Hsien Loong](/wiki/Lee_Hsien_Loong)'s absence. Within the PAP, Teo was First Assistant Secretary-General in the party's [Central Executive Committee](/wiki/Central_Executive_Committee_(PAP)) (CEC) before he was succeeded by [Heng Swee Keat](/wiki/Heng_Swee_Keat) in November 2018. ## Education Teo was educated at [St. Joseph's Institution](/wiki/St._Joseph%27s_Institution,_Singapore) before he was awarded the [President's Scholarship](/wiki/President%27s_Scholar) and [Singapore Armed Forces Overseas Scholarship](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces_Overseas_Scholarship) in 1973. He graduated from the [University of Manchester](/wiki/University_of_Manchester) in 1976 with a [Bachelor of Science](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Science) with first class honours degree in [electrical engineering](/wiki/Electrical_engineering) and [management science](/wiki/Management_science). He subsequently went on to complete a [Master of Science](/wiki/Master_of_Science) with distinction degree in [computing science](/wiki/Computing_science) at [Imperial College London](/wiki/Imperial_College_London) in 1977. He also completed a [Master of Public Administration](/wiki/Master_of_Public_Administration) degree at [Harvard Kennedy School](/wiki/Harvard_Kennedy_School) in 1986, where he was named a Littauer Fellow. ## Career ### Military career Teo joined the [Singapore Armed Forces](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces) (SAF) in 1972 and was commissioned as a [naval officer](/wiki/Naval_officer) at the [SAFTI Military Institute](/wiki/SAFTI_Military_Institute) in 1973. He went on to hold various command and staff appointments in the [Republic of Singapore Navy](/wiki/Republic_of_Singapore_Navy) (RSN) and the Joint Staff before his appointment as [Chief of Navy](/wiki/Chief_of_Navy_(Singapore)) in 1991 with the rank of [Rear-Admiral](/wiki/Rear-Admiral) (Two-Star) before leaving the SAF on 7 December 1992 to contest in the [1992 by-elections](/wiki/1992_Marine_Parade_by-election) in [Marine Parade GRC](/wiki/Marine_Parade_GRC). Teo was awarded the [Commendation Medal (Silver) (Military)](/wiki/Pingat_Penghargaan_(Tentera)) and the [Public Administration Medal (Gold) (Military)](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam_(Tentera)) in the 1981 and 1992 National Day Awards respectively. ### Political career Teo made his political debut in the [1992 by-elections](/wiki/1992_Marine_Parade_by-election) in [Marine Parade GRC](/wiki/Marine_Parade_Group_Representation_Constituency) as part of a four-member PAP team led by Prime Minister [Goh Chok Tong](/wiki/Goh_Chok_Tong). After the PAP team won 72.9% of the vote against three opposition parties, Teo was elected as the Member of Parliament (MP) representing the [Joo Chiat](/wiki/Joo_Chiat) ward of Marine Parade GRC. He was subsequently appointed as [Minister of State for Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Singapore)), [Minister of State for Communications](/wiki/Ministry_of_Communications_and_Information) and [Minister of State for Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)). In April 1995, Teo was appointed as [Senior Minister of State for Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)) and Acting [Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment). In January 1996, he was promoted to full Minister and given the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore) portfolios of Minister for the Environment and Second Minister for Defence. Teo switched to contesting in [Pasir Ris GRC](/wiki/Pasir_Ris_Group_Representation_Constituency) during the [1997 general election](/wiki/1997_Singaporean_general_election) and the four-member PAP team led by him won 70.9% of the vote against the [Workers' Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_(Singapore)). Teo thus elected as the MP representing the [Pasir Ris Loyang](/wiki/Loyang,_Singapore) ward of Pasir Ris GRC. In subsequent Cabinet reshuffles, he became [Minister for Education](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Singapore)) while continuing to serve as Second Minister for Defence. During the [2001 general election](/wiki/2001_Singaporean_general_election), Teo led the five-member PAP team contesting in the newly formed [Pasir Ris–Punggol GRC](/wiki/Pasir_Ris%E2%80%93Punggol_Group_Representation_Constituency) and won an uncontested walkover. After winning the general election, he continued to hold his previous Cabinet portfolios while becoming the MP representing the [Pasir Ris West](/wiki/Pasir_Ris) ward of Pasir Ris–Punggol GRC. On 1 August 2003, Teo was appointed as [Minister for Defence](/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Singapore)) and [Minister-in-charge of the Civil Service](/wiki/Singapore_Civil_Service). During the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election), Teo led a six-member PAP team to contest in Pasir–Ris Punggol GRC again and won 68.7% of the vote against the [Singapore Democratic Alliance](/wiki/Singapore_Democratic_Alliance). He retained his parliamentary seat and continued holding his Cabinet portfolios. On 1 April 2009, Teo was appointed as one of two [Deputy Prime Ministers](/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Singapore), in addition to his portfolios as Minister for Defence and Minister-in-charge of the Civil Service. Teo led a six-member PAP team to contest in Pasir–Ris Punggol GRC in the [2011 general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election) and won 64.79% of the vote against the [Singapore Democratic Alliance](/wiki/Singapore_Democratic_Alliance). On 18 May 2011, Teo relinquished his Cabinet portfolio of Minister for Defence and took up the positions of [Minister for Home Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Home_Affairs_(Singapore)) and [Coordinating Minister for National Security](/wiki/Coordinating_Minister_for_National_Security_(Singapore)), while concurrently serving as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister-in-charge of the Civil Service. On 1 May 2019, Teo relinquished his appointment as [Deputy Prime Minister](/wiki/Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Singapore) to become a [Senior Minister](/wiki/Senior_Minister_of_Singapore), while retaining his position as [Coordinating Minister for National Security](/wiki/Coordinating_Minister_for_National_Security_(Singapore)). In his new role, he also oversaw four departments under the [Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)); [Smart Nation and Digital Government Group](/wiki/Smart_Nation), [National Security Coordination Secretariat](/wiki/National_Security_Coordination_Secretariat), National Population and Talent Division, and the [National Climate Change Secretariat](/wiki/National_Climate_Change_Secretariat). On 21 April 2025, Teo announced that he will not be contesting for the [Pasir Ris–Changi GRC](/wiki/Pasir_Ris%E2%80%93Changi_Group_Representation_Constituency) in the [2025 general election](/wiki/2025_Singaporean_general_election). On 23 April, on the Nomination Day for the [2025 general election](/wiki/2025_Singaporean_general_election), Teo was not nominated as a candidate for any constituencies. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong later then announced Teo's retirement from politics in a Facebook post. Teo was then appointed Senior Advisor in the [Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)). ### Post political career On 6 June 2025, [Temasek Holdings](/wiki/Temasek_Holdings) announced that Teo will join its board of director on 1 July and succeed [Lim Boon Heng](/wiki/Lim_Boon_Heng) as chairman on 9 October. On 10 June, [GIC](/wiki/GIC_(sovereign_wealth_fund)) announced that Teo has resigned from its board of directors and as chairman of its international advisory board, effective 30 June. ## Personal life Teo was married to Chew Poh Yim, who was the director of the business consultancy and part-time marketing management at [Nanyang Polytechnic](/wiki/Nanyang_Polytechnic)'s School of Business Management. Chew graduated from the [University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology](/wiki/University_of_Manchester_Institute_of_Science_and_Technology) in 1977 with a [Bachelor of Science](/wiki/Bachelor_of_Science) with honours degree in [biochemistry](/wiki/Biochemistry). In 2015, she founded Stroke Support Station, a volunteering organisation that provides assistance to stroke survivors and caregivers. Chew died on 31 October 2021 at the age of 67. The couple have one son and one daughter. Teo was also the president of the [Singapore National Olympic Council](/wiki/Singapore_National_Olympic_Council) (SNOC) between 1998 and 2014, and an advisor to the Singapore Dragon Boat Association. ## Honours - 1981: [Pingat Penghargaan, Perak (Tentera)](/wiki/Pingat_Penghargaan_(Tentera)) - Commendation Medal (Silver) (Military) - 1992: [Pingat Pentadbiran Awam, Emas (Tentera)](/wiki/Pingat_Pentadbiran_Awam_(Tentera)) - Public Administration Medal (Gold) (Military) ## Bibliography - (in Chinese) Liu, Changping & Zhang, He, *风雨晚晴园(不应忘却的辛亥革命勋臣张永福)*, 中国文史 (2011), [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 9787503431098 - Teo Chee Hean on Singapore Prime Minister's Office - Teo Chee Hean on [Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore) - Teo Chee Hean on [Twitter](/wiki/Twitter) - Teo Chee Hean on [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook_(identifier)) Political officesPreceded by[Mah Bow Tan](/wiki/Mah_Bow_Tan) **[Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Minister_for_Environment_and_Water_Resources)** 1996–1997 Acting: 1995–1996Succeeded by[Lim Swee Say](/wiki/Lim_Swee_Say)**Recreated**Title last held by**[Lee Boon Yang](/wiki/Lee_Boon_Yang)** **[Second Minister for Defence](/wiki/Minister_for_Defence_(Singapore))** 1996–2003Succeeded by[Ng Eng Hen](/wiki/Ng_Eng_Hen)Preceded by[Lee Yock Suan](/wiki/Lee_Yock_Suan) **[Minister for Education](/wiki/Minister_for_Education_(Singapore))** 1997–2003Succeeded by[Tharman Shanmugaratnam](/wiki/Tharman_Shanmugaratnam)Preceded by[Tony Tan](/wiki/Tony_Tan_Keng_Yam) **[Minister for Defence](/wiki/Minister_for_Defence_(Singapore))** 2003–2011Succeeded by[Ng Eng Hen](/wiki/Ng_Eng_Hen)Preceded by[S. title: Teo Chee Hean
